KANNUR

Kannur is a district in the northern part of Kerala, known for its rich culture, history, and natural beauty. It is a place where you can witness the traditional art forms, festivals, and rituals of Kerala, as well as enjoy the scenic beaches, forts, and hills. Here are some of the tourist attractions in Kannur district that you can visit

Muzhappilangad Drive-in Beach: This is the longest drive-in beach in Asia, and one of the best places to visit in Kannur. You can drive your vehicle on the 4 km long stretch of sand, and enjoy the view of the Arabian Sea. You can also indulge in some water sports, such as parasailing, jet skiing, and surfing, or relax under the shade of the coconut trees. The beach is also famous for hosting the annual beach festival, which attracts thousands of tourists and locals

St. Angelo Fort: This is a historical fort built by the Portuguese in 1505, and later captured by the Dutch and the British. It is located on a cliff, overlooking the Mappila Bay, and offers a stunning view of the sea and the sunset. The fort has a triangular shape, with bastions, cannons, and a moat. It also has a chapel, a museum, and a garden inside. The fort is a protected monument and a popular tourist attraction

Parassinikadavu Muthappan Temple: This is a unique temple dedicated to Lord Muthappan, a manifestation of Lord Shiva and Lord Vishnu. The temple is situated on the banks of the Valapattanam River, and is famous for its ritual performance of Theyyam, a folk art form of Kerala. The Theyyam is performed every morning and evening, and attracts devotees and tourists alike. The temple also offers free meals to the visitors, and has a fish sanctuary nearby

Payyambalam Beach: This is a serene and beautiful beach in Kannur, ideal for relaxing and rejuvenating. It is a long and wide stretch of sand, with clear water and gentle waves. It is also a good place for swimming, boating, and fishing. The beach has a sculpture garden, a children’s park, and a war memorial nearby. The beach is also the venue for the annual sand art festival, which showcases the creativity and talent of the sand artists
